text:
DON LEMON: In the middle of
the president's tweet tirade

on Saturday morning
about President Obama

wiretapping his
phones he also took

the time to tweet about
Arnold Schwarzenegger
and The Apprentice.

And he said, Arnold
Schwarzenegger

isn't voluntarily
leaving The Apprentice.

He was fired by his bad,
pathetic ratings, not by me.
Sad end to great show.
What do you think?

- I think that Donald
Trump is in love
with Arnold Schwarzenegger.
DON LEMON: You stole the--

- That's what Arnold
Schwarzenegger thinks,
and I agree.

DON LEMON: OK so we spoke
with, Schwarzenegger

spoke with Michael
Smerconish on his radio show,
here's what he said.
She gave it away.

MICHAEL SMERCONISH:
Final question.

Unrelated subject, that I'd
be derelict if I didn't ask.

Why do you think the
president is fixated on you?

Why does he keep talking about
you through his Twitter feed?

ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER: I
think he's in love with me.

MICHAEL SMERCONISH:
Is that what it is?

ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER:
Yeah, I think so.

MICHAEL SMERCONISH: You've had
a long relationship with him.
ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER: Oh, yes.

MICHAEL SMERCONISH: That's
all you're saying on that.
Thank you, Governor.

ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER:
Absolutely.

- Well he also talks
a lot about Don.

DON LEMON: As they
say on Seinfeld,

not that there's anything
wrong with that, but go--

- Arnold Schwarzenegger is
the only guy who has a better
chest than Vladimir Putin.

- He talks a lot about you Don,
so maybe he's in love with you
as well.

DON LEMON: I've
always thought that, I

think that he really
likes me, that's
why he talks about me so much.

PARIS DENNARD: I
think the president
is in love with success.

And he said that the show
wasn't going to be successful,
and he turned out to be correct.

And so he likes to talk about
things that he's in love with.

DON LEMON: So he's in
love with Schwarzenegger,
who by anyone's--

anyone's standard
is a huge success.

He was governor, he's, you
know, so anyway, go on.

PETER BEINART: Right,
like, you know, we've

now become lulled into this
completely parallel universe

of Donald Trump, in which
all of a sudden, this
is just kind of normal.

You know, George W. Bush, when
he ran for president in 2000

said he was running
to restore the dignity

and honor of the office
after Bill Clinton, right.

There was a time
when Republicans
actually cared about that.

Now we have a President
of the United States

who just randomly insults
b-rate movie actors,

and we think, well, you know
it's kind of cute, right?
This is crazy.

It's just totally crazy,
we've just gotten used to it.
